Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1250342
Murray Webster
Lisa Walker
University of North Carolina, Charlotte

This project develops and elaborates theories of status generalization. These theories describe how status characteristics that confer advantages and disadvantages in the larger society (such as gender, education, or age) get "imported" and affect dimensions of power and prestige (such as participation rates, influence, and leadership choices) in face to face task groups. The work has led to theoretically guided interventions to reduce or eliminate unwanted status generalization from race, gender, ethnicity, and other status characteristics in schools and organizations. A previous NSF funded grant developed this research by adding effects of behavior patterns (such as deference and assertiveness) to status effects. This new project further expands the scope of this line of inquiry to include interactions of cultural beliefs (such as appropriate behaviors associated with gender) with status and behavior. The research will investigate how various combinations of status and behavior affect the formation of performance expectations within task work. The study will employ a complex experimental design to explore these relationships. Participants in the experiment will be male and female paid volunteers recruited from large classes.

Broader Impact

Results of this research contribute to the status generalization theoretical research program and can lay a foundation for further investigations of beliefs, structure and behavior. They will suggest new ways to control status effects by adding behavior and making cultural beliefs salient. They also help track changing cultural beliefs, such as possible decline in the significance of gender for task focused interaction. Findings also have implications for developing new experimental techniques that will be used by other investigators, training a graduate student in all stages of theory building, experimental design and operations, and data analysis and archiving. The project also will train undergraduates in recruiting, computer scheduling and face to face interviewing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes NSF 1260342

Murray Webster, Jr., and Lisa Slattery Walker

 

This award supported a program of laboratory experiments on ways that individuals interpret certain behavior patterns, inferences they make about performance competence, and effects on subsequent interaction in task groups. The research method was laboratory experiments supplemented by detailed interviews with group participants. The work was guided by a new elaboration of the theory of status characteristics and expectation states to encompass effects of certain behavior patterns.

This project was originally designed to investigate gender differences that had appeared in a previous project (NES SES 0351020) on those topics. In the previous work, it appeared that men were less concerned than women about reaching high quality conclusions in those groups. Besides possible implications for mixed gender work groups, that outcome was counter to theoretical predictions which presume that women and men respond the same ways to similar social situations. In this project, we conducted several partial replications of the earlier experiments, added new techniques that we developed to address possible gender differences in responses and to increase men’s concern with high quality performance, and fitted new behavioral models to the data to assess aspects of the causes of behavior in the experiments. The replications did not produce gender differences in behavior and did motivate men to focus intently on high quality task performance. Analyses and results are reported at professional meetings and in the publication attached, with acknowledgement of NSF support.

In this work, we developed, tested, and implemented a successful way to increase concern with task performance that we used in the replication. The research uses a well-established basic experimental design, and our techniques are now available for researchers investigating related theoretical and applied topics. We added to the confirmation status of the theoretical foundation and of the behavioral models applied to the experiments. We contributed to the science pipeline. We trained two graduate students, one woman and one man, in all aspects of experimental design and conduct; one is now in a doctoral program at Notre Dame and the other is completing an M.A. with us. We also trained six undergraduates of both genders in scheduling and interviewing, skills that other students have told us proved useful in job interviews and in later job performance. Overall, the project employed six women and two men, including a military veteran. We also updated and developed new computer programs in our laboratory to control communication and collect questionnaire and behavioral responses. The basic theory of behavior and perceived competence will function as basis for further elaboration and empirical research. Because behavioral patterns are at least partly voluntary, the research shows ways that individuals in task groups can overcome disadvantages associated with status characteristics, including gender and race.
